San Xavier del Bac

Spanish Colonial â€” 1692
Historic colonial site â€” location from NPS/state records
Established near Tohono O'odham water sources along the Santa Cruz River. The "White Dove of the Desert."
ðŸ“– Bolton, "Rim of Christendom" (1936); NPS National Register; Kessell, "Kiva, Cross, and Crown" (1979)

Hohokam Canal Reuse

Spanish Colonial â€” 1694
Historic colonial site â€” location from NPS/state records
Father Kino documented Pima Indians still using Hohokam canals for irrigation on the Gila River.
ðŸ“– Bolton, "Rim of Christendom" (1936); NPS National Register; Kessell, "Kiva, Cross, and Crown" (1979)

Presidio San AgustÃ­n del Tucson

Spanish Colonial â€” 1775
Historic colonial site â€” location from NPS/state records
Founded at the confluence of the Santa Cruz River and Rillito Creek â€” a natural indigenous gathering point.
ðŸ“– Bolton, "Rim of Christendom" (1936); NPS National Register; Kessell, "Kiva, Cross, and Crown" (1979)

Presidio Santa Cruz de Terrenate

Spanish Colonial â€” 1776
Historic colonial site â€” location from NPS/state records
Built on the San Pedro River near indigenous water sources. Abandoned after Apache attacks.
ðŸ“– Bolton, "Rim of Christendom" (1936); NPS National Register; Kessell, "Kiva, Cross, and Crown" (1979)

Santa Fe

Spanish Colonial â€” 1610
Historic colonial site â€” location from NPS/state records
Capital established near Pueblo water management systems. Santa Fe River was diverted into acequias.
ðŸ“– Bolton, "Rim of Christendom" (1936); NPS National Register; Kessell, "Kiva, Cross, and Crown" (1979)

Taos Pueblo Encounter

Spanish Colonial â€” 1540
Historic colonial site â€” location from NPS/state records
Coronado expedition reached Taos Pueblo, continuously inhabited 1000+ years along the Rio Pueblo de Taos.
ðŸ“– Bolton, "Rim of Christendom" (1936); NPS National Register; Kessell, "Kiva, Cross, and Crown" (1979)

Grand Canyon Puebloan Sites

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
4,300+ sites spanning 12,000 years. Pictographs, granaries, seasonal camps near springs and the river.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Chaco Canyon

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Center of Ancestral Puebloan civilization ~850-1150 CE. Water management was central â€” check dams, irrigation channels, collection basins.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Aztec Ruins

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Great house on the Animas River connected to Chaco by ancient road. ~1100-1300 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Mesa Verde

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
600+ cliff dwellings built ~1190-1300 CE near springs seeping from sandstone. Left ~1300 CE, likely drought.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Pueblo Grande

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Platform mound on Hohokam canals. Park of Four Waters preserves visible canal remnants. Museum in Phoenix.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Casa Grande Ruins

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
4-story Hohokam structure ~1350 CE on the Gila River. Largest pre-contact structure in the SW.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Montezuma Castle

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Sinagua cliff dwelling above Beaver Creek. 20 rooms, 5 stories. ~1100-1425 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Montezuma Well

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Natural sinkhole fed by 1.5M gallons/day from springs. Sinagua irrigation ditches still carry water today.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Tuzigoot

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Large Sinagua pueblo, 110 rooms overlooking Verde River. ~1125-1400 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Puerco Pueblo

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
100-room pueblo on the Puerco River with solar calendar petroglyphs. ~1250-1380 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Navajo National Monument

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Betatakin & Keet Seel cliff dwellings near springs. ~1250-1300 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Homolovi

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Ancestral Hopi pueblos on the Little Colorado River. ~1260-1400 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

El Morro

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Permanent pool at base of sandstone mesa attracted indigenous peoples then Spanish. Atsinna Pueblo ~1275-1350 CE.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Taos Pueblo

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Continuously inhabited 1000+ years. Rio Pueblo flows through center. UNESCO World Heritage Site.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Acoma Pueblo (Sky City)

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Atop 367-ft mesa since ~1100 CE. Water cisterns carved into rock. One of oldest continuously inhabited settlements in North America.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Monument Valley

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Sacred Navajo landscape. Seasonal washes and springs in sandstone. Petroglyphs in sheltered alcoves.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Bandelier

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Frijoles Canyon year-round stream supported large community ~1150-1550 CE. Cavate dwellings in volcanic tuff.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Snaketown

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Largest Hohokam village ~300 BCE-1100 CE. 100+ pit houses, ball courts. On Gila River Indian Reservation (closed to public).
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

El Malpais

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
Lava tubes & natural cisterns provided water/shelter. Multi-era petroglyphs throughout.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)

Park of the Canals

Indigenous Site â€” Southwest
Archaeological/cultural site â€” location from NPS, BLM, or tribal records
One of few places to see remnants of Hohokam canals dug before the time of Christ. Mesa, AZ.
ðŸ“– NPS site documentation; Archaeology Southwest; Lekson, "A History of the Ancient Southwest" (2009)
